Content: Schafer: I need to get accustomed to money being around.
That's the thing.
This is for the therapy, the physical therapy of getting me used to actually not being afraid of money.
Offscreen voice: Richard Branson does the same thing.
Schafer: Ah! You guys, what is this stuff that's all over me?
Offscreen voice: Beautiful.
Schafer: I can't apply it to myself..
Offscreen voice: Oh my God.
Schafer: I can't self-terminate.
Offscreen voice: Help me apply money.
Schafer: I can't self-monetize.
Schafer: So this is a more recent, uh point-and-click adventure game.
I have to show you someone else's, because I haven't made one in a long time.
I used to make them back in the '90s.
This is Machinarium.
You role play this little robot and you click around.
And these kind of games, you walk the character around by clicking on the ground somewhere and pull on this handle here.
And then I can make this mine cart come through the room.
Shahani: I'm sorry. What's that?
Schafer: I pulled this handle, oh, that's right.
This doesn't work until I do this.
That's what a lot of adventure game playing is like.
You're like, oh, this doesn't, why doesn't this work?
Oh, I need this gear first.
I need to get the gear on the sprocket.
And so they're, they move at a slower pace.
And some people really like that.
But it also means they're not exactly as attention-getting and as visceral and maybe as a big block buster action game.
And it led us to this point now where it's really hard to get one of these games made these days,
or at least get funding for it from a publisher.
Shahani: Before getting into all that, what put you on the map?
Like, just describe the game that got you into game famous.
Schafer: Game famous.
You know, we just, each game we made in the '90s, we got a little more recognition for it.
And we were always pretty savvy about getting our names on the box, you know, so we're, hey.
You know, you have to kind of act like you're famous before you're famous.
That sounds funny.
I learned that from an interview with David Lee Roth about Van Halen.
Like we always acted like we were hot shit.
We had a big hit, Full Throttle, it's called Full Throttle and it sold a million copies
and that was really big for those PC graphic adventures.
And then I made a game called Grim Fandango and that won Game of the Year with Game Spot
and that was the big thing that helped a lot.
Grim Fandango is set in the Land of the Dead, yeah.
And it was, it sold about half a million units and it was seen as not being commercially successful.
And it was one of the reasons that adventure games died.
I mean, I heard a friend of mine, who worked in another game company, saying we tried to get an adventure game made
and they said, well look, you know, Grim Fandango didn't do that well.
So obviously, you know, it was a good game, it won Game of the Year.
And if Game of the Year can't sell, you know, as many copies as it needs to, then maybe that genre's dead.
So I feel some responsibility to make a good game and make it do well.
Rice: He's been excited about it.
I mean, he's wanted to return to adventure games for a while and it's just been a matter of not knowing how to make that happen.
Schafer: But fans are always saying they would want, they want one, but a publisher would say, we can't make money doing those.
So something like Kickstarter shows up, which is this crowd sourcing website, where everybody can back a project.
You pitch your project and you get backers and then if you meet your goals, you get the money and you build your project.
Doing an adventure game is interesting, because it's the only, like the only way you could do that,
letting the fans like, kind of put their money where their mouth is.
Is it that? Wait a second.
Did I get that backwards? Yeah.
Host: No, you're right. Yeah.
Some loud mouth fan, no, I don't want to buy Trenched, but what about an adventure game?
Schafer: Exactly.
Shahani: Explain your Kickstarter campaign.
What have you just done?
Schafer: Yeah. What have we done?
Schafer: Oh, sorry. I didn't see you there.
You caught me indulging in one of my many impressive hobbies.
I'm Tim Schafer.
Schafer: And so we put a pitch video up where we said we want to make a game.
And the idea was, what if we made one of these adventure games that most publishers don't want to fund these days?
And one of my favorite types of games to make is adventure games.
But these days, it seems like adventure games are almost a bit of a lost art form.
They exist in our dreams and our memories and in Germany.
Schafer: Maybe that would get people excited about getting a chance to do something that couldn't be funded any other way.
Schafer: It's perfect.
We got the perfect team here at Double Fine to make it.
We got the inventor of the genre here, Ron Gilbert.
Oh, look! There he is right now.
Maybe he'll help us.
He'll help us.
Gilbert: You know, we've always talked about wanting to do, you know, more classic adventure stuff.
And so doing the Kickstarter thing, it's like, yeah, that sounds, I mean, that sounds really like an interesting idea.
I think we were both very skeptical about the amount of money.
Schafer: So, we are asking for this much to make the game and this much to film it.
And that may seem like a lot of money, but it's really not that much for a game budget these days.
It's pretty small, actually.
Schafer: And I just never thought you could get the kind of money that would actually pay for a whole game budget.
Schafer: Hello, potential backers.
I could do all three options.
Thank you for donating well over the amount we asked for.
That's so great.
We have too much money now.
Damn you!
Why haven't anyone given us any money?
I'm so sad.
That doesn't seem believable.
Yeah, we're not going to use that one.
Or just moderately, hello.
Thank you for dedicating the appropriate amount of...
Schafer: Because the previous projects in Kickstarter had only been, I don't know what the maximum was before then,
but it looked like they're like forty grand.
You know, I mean, we're used to making projects that were like, you know, BrÃ¼tal.
Like 20 million dollars and these smaller games, like two million.
It was like, no way you can get two million from Kickstarter.
Could you?
Schafer: I hope this works out, because it is kind of, that enough people got together,
are they going to actually make a game like this happen?
A game like, that we haven't really been able to make happen for business reasons for like, many, many years.
Gilbert: Or we'll just prove all those publishers right.
Schafer: Or we'll just prove them all right.
Schafer: No, I mean nothing I had done before prepared me for what it's like to work with publishers.
Rice: When you're working with a publisher, a lot of times they get involved with design decisions.
And you have to make compromises.
Gilbert: You know, if a publisher is out there, from the outside kind of poking in and making you do things.
You know, that's where I think things can kind of come off the rails.
Schafer: And the way it felt, I don't know if this makes any sense, but my head, like the creative process of making a game was like,
you look at a field of floating, multi-colored dots, drifting slowly to the ground.
And eventually when they hit the ground, they're going to make like a painting on the floor.
But you've got to kind of like move them around, give them the right and see.
And then as they fall, you start to see where you need more color and you move them around and slowly they settle and you just add a sound.
And then you're done.
So it'd be like, Tim, what do you do with that green dot?
Phew, I can't tell you.
You're like, ok, that dot?
Can we just nail that down here.
Can we just say what that's going to be?
And you're like, no.
So let's just say where all the red dots are going to be, ok.
Could you just nail all the red dots down?
Like, no!
How about if we just start on this edge and we just take all the dots, like this and just nail all those dots.
No!
Rice: Yeah. The games industry as a whole, I think, is in a really weird spot where it's like we're,
like the film industry used to be way back in the day.
Where the publishers are running mostly everything.
That's kind of how it was for a long time and it's only now that people are starting to like
seek out the creators of the games.
That people who are making the game and try to actually support those people and lift them up a bit.
Young Man: Because Tim Schafer has consistently put out quality games.
Man: Games that have very large and dedicated followings.
Man: People would probably pay him just to spit on their screen.
Young Man: And we do appreciate that.
We show our appreciation by doing what we've done.
By giving them the funding for this game in eight hours.
Rice: The whole like past month has been like a complete blur.
It's gone so quick.
But, yeah, we were in Vegas for DICE the day that we launched.
Schafer: And we'd had a hard month, because we had a game cancel.
The whole team, we're trying to figure out whether we could swing having this team stay on
or do we have to let go of twelve people to keep the company afloat?
We've never laid off anyone for money before.
So we were, and even besides the financial concerns, it was just such a, it doesn't feel like you're winning when you have a game canceled.
You feel like it's a big, you know, you've lost.
Schafer: I'm about to launch our first Kickstarter project.
Rice: It kind of just all came together right when we were out there and we had a bit of time before a meeting and we're like,
we could launch this today.
Schafer: Yeah, I did have to like decide, well, we'll launch our Kickstarter.
That, for time, we're like I guess $200,000.
We could make something for $200,000.
And I had to accept it, I might only get $200,000, right?
And then when I was nervous about it, so I upped it to three, right.
And so it was like, yeah, we can make something for $300,000.
Because we could.
You know, we'd been talking about iPhone games recently and it's like three people for six months or something like that.
Yeah, we could make something with three people and six months.
It would look like a flash game or it'd look like an iPhone game, but it would technically be a game.
By all scientific definitions.
Schafer: I'm nervous.
Launch.
Review, i'll have to review it.
Rice: Oh, man. That was such a letdown!
Schafer: OK. No, no, that's just fine print.
It's just that I never read these things.
Should I do it?
Rice: Yeah, do it.
Schafer: It couldn't hurt, right?
Rice: It could, but we're not going to let it.
Schafer: Whoo!
Rice: I remember like as soon as we hit it up and we refresh, it was like at $30.
We're like, holy crap! There's already $30.
Schafer: I think I'm going to look at how much, I don't care about money.
I'm not going to look. I'm going to look, just one second.
Rice: What are we at?
OK, so we posted this, what? Two hours ago, right?
Schafer: Two hours ago.
We launched our Kickstarter project two hours ago.
A hundred and six, I can't count so high.
It's such a high number, that's crazy.
It's too much money.
Rice: Yeah. So when we hit a million, that was definitely like, that was the day after.
One day after we launched, right?
Rice: What are we at?
Schafer: I want to just say I love you guys and not for the money.
Offscreen: 999,700!
Muir: Oh my god, they're counting down to a refresh.
Muir: Oh my God! It's so exciting.
Rice: What's the number?
Offscreen: Refresh! Refresh!
Min: The internet has crashed.
No!
Min: The internet has crashed.
Rice: And what? No!
Schafer: Where's my phone?
Muir: The Internet's crashed.
[Offscreen Yelling] [Distortion]
I think they all died. They're dying!
Are you guys ok? What happened?
Oh, they're being crushed. It's horrible.
Muir: Oh, no! No!
What happened?
[Distortion] Muir: It's a million dollars!
Rice: Is it?
Muir: That's what a million dollars sounds like.
Offscreen: What do you mean it crashed?
Offscreen: Kickstarter crashed.
Muir: Kickstarter crashed!
Schafer: No.
[Offscreen yelling] Rice: Yeah, that was definitely one of the high points,
where it was like, holy crap -- This is a huge thing.
Muir: Whoo! A million in 24 hours.
Tim Schafer, you just made a million dollars in 24 hours!
What do you, what are you doing?
Schafer: Yeah! I got to make a game.
Newscaster: Over the last few days, Tim Schafer from Double Fine took crowd funding site, Kickstarter to fund his next game.
Schafer: It feels like a happening. You know what I mean?
Like it feels like an event.
Newscaster: They're raising money at a clip of a thousand dollars per minute.
It's incredible.
Host: One question that is on everybody's mind.
You get the million dollars.
Did you immediately withdraw it all?
Put it into a vault and then dive into it like Scrooge McDuck style?
Schafer: Then during Kickstarter, it made it, I don't know what it was,
but it made everyone just take that big basket of money and shake it out over our heads.
It really was like the end of "It's a Wonderful Life".
[Music] Offscreen: So excited.
Offscreen: Thumbs up?
Man: Thumbs up, yes.
That was pretty amazing.
I told you, adventure games are not dead!
The thing that I noticed was that it was just such a morale boost to the whole team.
And you know, I think it just felt like a lot of goodwill and love coming towards the company and everyone got super excited about it.
And because it was like this feeling of like, we knew those people were there, we knew they were.
But, because sometimes they don't show up when you make a game.
You know, you make a game, you release it, you know, like I thought it was going to sell a lot and it didn't.
You're like, where are all those people that it feels like, there's all this goodwill out there.
Man #1: It's two million.
Man #2: One of us has to stop shaving.
Man #2: He has to shave my scrotum if it gets to two million.
Man #1: Only if he agrees to do it on camera.
Offscreen: Congratulations.
Schafer: It had been a long time since we had experience where it felt like we were the winners.
We were at DICE and I was walking through DICE, feeling like a winner, which is really kind of like,
not that I feel like a loser, but usually feel like the alternative, alternative to money.
I mean i'm proud of all our games and I wouldn't switch them with anyone else's games,
but usually walking in a convention like that, you're talking to the, you know, the people who made Uncharted
and they're, they're really nice and you're like, ah.
Congratulations on the game.
Did really well for you.
And like, you don't often feel like, you feel like they're like the family member who's like still living at home.
You know, like yeah.
They're all really nice to us, but you know, we haven't, it's different when you make a bunch of money.
Schafer: And we raised 1.7 million dollars on Kickstarter.
[Applause] Schafer: Is that auto refreshing?
Everyone: Yes.
Schafer: We were in the hotel room and I was listening on the Skype, on the iPad
and you just remember like, click, click, aha, aha, then all of a sudden, whooo!
Schafer: Distortion sound as everyone lost their shit.
And right now we're at almost 2.5 million dollars.
and we have six more days to go.
Rice, Offscreen: Everything moved really quickly and I actually didn't really have a chance
to like let everything sit in until yesterday, when it finished.
And I was like, finally it like hit me and it was like, holy crap.
We did something really crazy here.
Schafer: 2 minutes!
[Crowd shouting and cheering] So like we cleared in advance
I'm going to shake this up and I'm going to spray it all over your head.
Why is that...
Ron!
My God, that's terrible for your teeth.
Offscreen: Two minutes!
Two minutes.
[Pop] Offscreen: Premature! Premature!
Gilbert: There's still a part of my skeptical pessimistic brain that says, well, you can never do this again.
That this was really kind of this one time perfect storm thing.
But I don't know. I mean, maybe not.
[Music] [Cheering]
I've been so happy about that ever since Kickstarter started,
just thinking about how, I still have to answer to people.
Like people funded the game, you know.
But they're exactly the people I want to answer to.
Those are the people I'm making dots for, right?
And all those things like, and so it's like, it's just this really liberating,
freeing thing to just think that I'm just going to have to worry about how good the game is, almost nothing else.
[Music] Schafer: I love you guys!
It has been an amazing experience. So much love.
We know there's not, it's not all about us and Double Fine, but about you, the fans and what you guys want to say
and do with your money and choose to do.
And make things happen for yourself.
I mean, I don't want to make a huge speech here, because I'll be all choked up.
Gilbert: Too late.
Schafer: But I just, I don't want to say this is the end of the, you know, the whole game industry as we know it.
It's not, it's not.
And it's not, again it's not like we're total replacement of all publishers and publishing games.
There's still going to be, there still might be a few games made by publishers after today.
Just a couple games.
But it does mean if you've ever been told that your part of a niche market, if you've ever like, if you've ever like,
when you're a kid and you had your favorite TV show cancelled or you hear about your favorite band
being dropped by their label for not selling enough and you've just been like why does a big company get to choose
what music I listen to or what movies I watch or what TV shows I watch or what game I get to play,
now you know that they can't do that anymore.
You can choose. So thanks everybody.
[Cheering] Thank you to the team!
Everybody!
Thanks to my parents for backing the project and everybody else's parents who backed the project.
Does anybody else want to thank anybody?
Kipnis: Thank you Tim!
Thank you!
Thanks everyone and now we dance.
[Cheering] Ron's dancing!
[Music]
